elements.content: The novel gadolinium(III) complex of formula [Gd2(mal)3(H2O)6] (1) (H2mal = 1,3-propanedioic acid) has been prepared and characterized by X-ray diffraction analysis. Crystal data for 1:  monoclinic, space group I2/a, a = 11.1064(10) Å, b = 12.2524(10) Å, c = 13.6098(2) Å, β = 92.925(10)°, U = 1849.5(3) Å3, Z = 4. Compound 1 is a three-dimensional network made up of malonate-bridged gadolinium(III) ions where the malonate exhibits two bridging modes, η5-bidentate + unidentate and η3:η3 + bis(unidentate). The gadolinium atom is nine-coordinate with three water molecules and six malonate oxygen atoms from three malonate ligands forming a distorted monocapped square antiprism. The shortest metal−metal separations are 4.2763(3) Å [through the oxo-carboxylate bridge] and 6.541(3) Å [through the carboxylate in the anti − syn coordination mode]. The value of the angle at the oxo-carboxylate atom is 116.8(2)°. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements reveal the occurrence of a significant ferromagnetic interaction through the oxo-carboxylate pathway (J = +0.048(1) cm-1, H = −JS Gd(1)·S Gd(1a)).
elements.clean_text: The novel gadolinium(III) complex of formula [Gd2(mal)3(H2O)6] (1) (H2mal = 1,3-propanedioic acid) has been prepared and characterized by X-ray diffraction analysis. Crystal data for 1: monoclinic, space group I2/a, a = 11.1064(10) Å, b = 12.2524(10) Å, c = 13.6098(2) Å, β = 92.925(10)°, U = 1849.5(3) Å3, Z = 4. Compound 1 is a three-dimensional network made up of malonate-bridged gadolinium(III) ions where the malonate exhibits two bridging modes, η5-bidentate + unidentate and η3:η3 + bis(unidentate). The gadolinium atom is nine-coordinate with three water molecules and six malonate oxygen atoms from three malonate ligands forming a distorted monocapped square antiprism. The shortest metal-metal separations are 4.2763(3) Å [through the oxo-carboxylate bridge] and 6.541(3) Å [through the carboxylate in the anti - syn coordination mode]. The value of the angle at the oxo-carboxylate atom is 116.8(2)°. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements reveal the occurrence of a significant ferromagnetic interaction through the oxo-carboxylate pathway (J = +0.048(1) cm-1, H = -JS Gd(1)⋅S Gd(1a)).

elements.content: A ferromagnetic interaction (J = +0.048(1) cm-1) between pairs of Gd(III) ions separated by 4.3 Å through an oxo-carboxylate bridging atom is observed in the three-dimensional malonato-bridged complex of formula [Gd2(mal)3(H2O)6] (1) (H2mal = 1,3-propanedioic acid). Antiferromagnetic interactions between Gd(III) ions were found through this bridging pathway in previous magneto-structurally characterized examples.
elements.clean_text: A ferromagnetic interaction (J = +0.048(1) cm-1) between pairs of Gd(III) ions separated by 4.3 Å through an oxo-carboxylate bridging atom is observed in the three-dimensional malonato-bridged complex of formula [Gd2(mal)3(H2O)6] (1) (H2mal = 1,3-propanedioic acid). Antiferromagnetic interactions between Gd(III) ions were found through this bridging pathway in previous magneto-structurally characterized examples.

elements.content: Coordination compounds with lanthanide cations have attracted the interest of researchers in materials science because of their luminescence and/or magnetic properties. The rather large magnetic moment of most of the lanthanide(III) cations [Ln(III)] together with their anisotropy makes these ions very appealing in the preparation of magnetic materials. A great number of 4f−3d or 4f−organic radical systems have been described. Recent studies concerning the use of malonate (dianion of 1,3-propanedioic acid, mal2-) as a ligand toward 3dand 4f cations have shown that a great variety of polymeric structures can be obtained due to the different coordination modes adopted by this ligand.
elements.clean_text: Coordination compounds with lanthanide cations have attracted the interest of researchers in materials science because of their luminescence and/or magnetic properties. The rather large magnetic moment of most of the lanthanide(III) cations [Ln(III)] together with their anisotropy makes these ions very appealing in the preparation of magnetic materials. A great number of 4f-3d or 4f-organic radical systems have been described. Recent studies concerning the use of malonate (dianion of 1,3-propanedioic acid, mal2-) as a ligand toward 3dand 4f cations have shown that a great variety of polymeric structures can be obtained due to the different coordination modes adopted by this ligand.

elements.content: In the present work, we report the preparation, X-ray structural analysis, and variable-temperature magnetic study of the first example of a three-dimensional malonate-bridged compound of Gd(III) which exhibits ferromagnetic coupling between pairs of Gd(III) ions.
elements.clean_text: In the present work, we report the preparation, X-ray structural analysis, and variable-temperature magnetic study of the first example of a three-dimensional malonate-bridged compound of Gd(III) which exhibits ferromagnetic coupling between pairs of Gd(III) ions.

elements.content: The structure of 1 consists of a three-dimensional arrangement of triaquagadolinium(III) units bridged by malonate groups (see Figure ) which results from the cross-linking of the single chains running parallel to the c axis (Figure a) and the double zigzag chains which grow in the ab plane (Figure b). Extensive hydrogen bonds involving carboxylate groups and water molecules [2.731(3) and 2.723(3) Å for O(1W)·· O(2a) and O(2W)···O(4b), respectively] contribute to the stabilization of the crystal structure.
elements.clean_text: The structure of 1 consists of a three-dimensional arrangement of triaquagadolinium(III) units bridged by malonate groups (see Figure ) which results from the cross-linking of the single chains running parallel to the c axis (Figure a) and the double zigzag chains which grow in the ab plane (Figure b). Extensive hydrogen bonds involving carboxylate groups and water molecules [2.731(3) and 2.723(3) Å for O(1W)⋅⋅ O(2a) and O(2W)⋅⋅⋅O(4b), respectively] contribute to the stabilization of the crystal structure.

elements.content: (a) Projection of the double chains down theb axis. (b) Projection of the single chains down the c axis. Water molecules, malonate ligands [L1 in part a and L2 in part b], and hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Projection of the double chains down theb axis. (b) Projection of the single chains down the c axis. Water molecules, malonate ligands [L1 in part a and L2 in part b], and hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The gadolinium atoms in [Gd2(mal)3(H2O)6] are surrounded by nine oxygen atoms:  six oxygen atoms from three malonate ligands and three coordinated water molecules build a distorted monocapped square antiprism surrounding. Similar geometries are observed in other malonate-containing lanthanide complexes. Three aspects concerning the Gd−O bond distances are to be outlined:  (i) the average value of the Gd(1)−O(mal) bonds is 2.454(2) Å; (ii) there exists a long bond between Gd(1) and the O(6) carboxylate-oxygen [2.597(2) Å] which is involved in the formation of the oxo-bridge Gd(1)−O(6)−Gd(1a) (see Figure ); (iii) the Gd−O(w) bond lengths vary in the range 2.456(2)−2.509(2) Å, values which are slightly longer than those of gadolinium to carboxylate oxygens [2.308−2.597 Å].
elements.clean_text: The gadolinium atoms in [Gd2(mal)3(H2O)6] are surrounded by nine oxygen atoms: six oxygen atoms from three malonate ligands and three coordinated water molecules build a distorted monocapped square antiprism surrounding. Similar geometries are observed in other malonate-containing lanthanide complexes. Three aspects concerning the Gd-O bond distances are to be outlined: (i) the average value of the Gd(1)-O(mal) bonds is 2.454(2) Å; (ii) there exists a long bond between Gd(1) and the O(6) carboxylate-oxygen [2.597(2) Å] which is involved in the formation of the oxo-bridge Gd(1)-O(6)-Gd(1a) (see Figure ); (iii) the Gd-O(w) bond lengths vary in the range 2.456(2)-2.509(2) Å, values which are slightly longer than those of gadolinium to carboxylate oxygens [2.308-2.597 Å].

elements.content: Coordination geometry of the gadolinium cation in1. Symmetry codes: (a) = 1/2 − x, 1/2 − y, 1/2 − z; (b) = 1 − x, 1/2 + y, 1/2 − z.
elements.clean_text: 3  Coordination geometry of the gadolinium cation in1. Symmetry codes: (a)=1/2-x,1/2-y,1/2-z;(b)=1-x,1/2+y,1/2-z.

elements.content: There are two crystallographically independent malonate units with different arrangements which are noted as L1 and L2 in Chart . The L1 mode links two gadolinium atoms acting simultaneously as bidentate chelate and monodentate. The chelate ring of L1 has a boat conformation, and its carboxylate bridge adopts the anti − syn conformation. The malonate ligand of the L2 unit links four gadolinium atoms through two bidentate four-membered chelate rings and two monodentate interactions with the anti − anti conformation. The average C−O bond distances and O−C−O bond angles in L1 and L2 are 1.262(17) Å and 121.8(4)°, respectively. These values are in agreement with the previously reported malonate-containing lanthanide complexes. The shortest metal−metal separations are 4.2763(3) Å for Gd(1)···Gd(1a) [through the O(6) oxo-carboxylate oxygen atom] and 6.541(3) Å for Gd(1)···Gd(1b) [through the O(2)C(1)O(1)-carboxylate group].
elements.clean_text: There are two crystallographically independent malonate units with different arrangements which are noted as L1 and L2 in Chart . The L1 mode links two gadolinium atoms acting simultaneously as bidentate chelate and monodentate. The chelate ring of L1 has a boat conformation, and its carboxylate bridge adopts the anti - syn conformation. The malonate ligand of the L2 unit links four gadolinium atoms through two bidentate four-membered chelate rings and two monodentate interactions with the anti - anti conformation. The average C-O bond distances and O-C-O bond angles in L1 and L2 are 1.262(17) Å and 121.8(4)°, respectively. These values are in agreement with the previously reported malonate-containing lanthanide complexes. The shortest  metal-metal separations are 4.2763(3) Å for Gd(1)⋅⋅⋅Gd(1a) [through the O(6) oxo-carboxylate oxygen atom] and 6.541(3) Å for Gd(1)⋅⋅⋅Gd(1b) [through the O(2)C(1)O(1)-carboxylate group].

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="chart" id="ic034175wc00001" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="ic034175wc00001.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

The temperature dependence of the χM T product for 1 [χM is the magnetic susceptibility per two Gd(III) ions] is shown in Figure . At room temperature, χM T is ca. 15.75 cm3 mol-1 K, a value which is as expected for two magnetically isolated S = 7/2 local spins with g = 2.0. This value remains practically constant when cooling to 60 K, and further, it sharply increases to 18.6 cm3 mol-1 K at 2.0 K. This curve is typical of a weak but significant ferromagnetic interaction between two gadolinium(III) ions. Although two exchange pathways are possible (oxo-carboxylato and carboxylato bridges), the shorter metal−metal separation through the oxo-carboxylate bridge, together with its greater efficiency to mediate exchange interactions versus that of the more extended carboxylato bridge, allows us to discard the latter one. Consequently, we analyze the magnetic properties of 1 through a simple dimer law deduced from the isotropic spin Hamiltonian H = −JS Gd(1)·S Gd(1a). The best-fit parameters are the following:  J = +0.05 cm-1, g = 2.0, and R = 1.5 × 10-5 (R is the agreement factor defined as ∑[(χM T)obs − (χM T)calcd]2/∑[(χM T)obs]2). The magnetization plot per two Gd(III) ions (see inset of Figure ) at 2.0 K closely follows the Brillouin function per two magnetically isolated Gd(III) ions with g = 2.0 because of the weak ferromagnetic interaction; the population of the ground spin state S = 7 in our experimental conditions is very small. To our knowledge, this is the first time that a ferromagnetic interaction is observed between two gadolinium(III) ions in a structurally characterized complex. Previous results on structurally characterized homopolynuclear Gd(III) complexes with an oxygen bridge (see S2 and references included) reveal the occurrence of antiferromagnetic interactions varying in the range −0.05 to −0.21 cm-1. Only in a very recent report concerning the compound of formula [GdL3(H2O)2]2 (HL = salicylic acid) was a ferromagnetic coupling of the same magnitude of that of 1 observed, but the structure of this compound remains unknown.
elements.clean_text: The temperature dependence of the χM T product for 1 [χM is the magnetic susceptibility per two Gd(III) ions] is shown in Figure . At room temperature, χM T is ca. 15.75 cm3 mol-1 K, a value which is as expected for two magnetically isolated S = 7/2 local spins with g = 2.0. This value remains practically constant when cooling to 60 K, and further, it sharply increases to 18.6 cm3 mol-1 K at 2.0 K. This curve is typical of a weak but significant ferromagnetic interaction between two gadolinium(III) ions. Although two exchange pathways are possible (oxo-carboxylato and carboxylato bridges), the shorter metal-metal separation through the oxo-carboxylate bridge, together with its greater efficiency to mediate exchange interactions versus that of the more extended carboxylato bridge, allows us to discard the latter one. Consequently, we analyze the magnetic properties of 1 through a simple dimer law deduced from the isotropic spin Hamiltonian H = -JS Gd(1)⋅S Gd(1a). The best-fit parameters are the following: J = +0.05 cm-1, g = 2.0, and R = 1.5 × 10-5 (R is the agreement factor defined as ∑[(χM T)obs - (χM T)calcd]2/∑[(χM T)obs]2). The magnetization plot per two Gd(III) ions (see inset of Figure ) at 2.0 K closely follows the Brillouin function per two magnetically isolated Gd(III) ions with g = 2.0 because of the weak ferromagnetic interaction; the population of the ground spin state S = 7 in our experimental conditions is very small. To our knowledge, this is the first time that a ferromagnetic interaction is observed between two gadolinium(III) ions in a structurally characterized complex. Previous results on structurally characterized homopolynuclear Gd(III) complexes with an oxygen bridge (see S2 and references included) reveal the occurrence of antiferromagnetic interactions varying in the range -0.05 to -0.21 cm-1. Only in a very recent report concerning the compound of formula [GdL3(H2O)2]2 (HL = salicylic acid) was a ferromagnetic coupling of the same magnitude of that of 1 observed, but the structure of this compound remains unknown.

elements.content: Temperature dependence of the χM T product of 1:  (○) experimental data; () best-fit curve (see text). The inset shows the M (○) versus H plot at 2 K [the solid line () is the Brillouin function for two magnetically isolated Gd(III) ions with g = 2.0].
elements.clean_text: 4  Temperature dependence of the χM T product of 1: (○) experimental data; () best-fit curve (see text). The inset shows the M (○) versus H plot at 2 K [the solid line () is the Brillouin function for two magnetically isolated Gd(III) ions with g = 2.0].

elements.content: At this stage, we can only suggest that the ferromagnetic coupling observed in 1 is most likely due to the accidental orthogonality between the magnetic orbitals of the two interacting Gd(III) ions, the value of the angle at the oxo-bridge, and the Gd···Gd separation through it, which plays the major role. This situation remains that of the di-μ-hydroxodicopper(II) family where the intradimer magnetic coupling is ferro- or antiferromagnetic depending mainly on the value of the angle at the hydroxo bridge. The occurrence of more than one possible exchange pathway in 1 (carboxylate and oxo) makes difficult the identification of crucial factors governing the ferromagnetic coupling. Further work is in progress (magneto-structural studies and DFT type calculations) to design and characterize new examples of ferromagnetically coupled oxo-bridged Gd(III) compounds in order to clarify the exchange mechanism in these systems.
elements.clean_text: At this stage, we can only suggest that the ferromagnetic coupling observed in 1 is most likely due to the accidental orthogonality between the magnetic orbitals of the two interacting Gd(III) ions, the value of the angle at the oxo-bridge, and the Gd⋅⋅⋅Gd separation through it, which plays the major role. This situation remains that of the di-μ-hydroxodicopper(II) family where the intradimer magnetic coupling is ferro- or antiferromagnetic depending mainly on the value of the angle at the hydroxo bridge. The occurrence of more than one possible exchange pathway in 1 (carboxylate and oxo) makes difficult the identification of crucial factors governing the ferromagnetic coupling. Further work is in progress (magneto-structural studies and DFT type calculations) to design and characterize new examples of ferromagnetically coupled oxo-bridged Gd(III) compounds in order to clarify the exchange mechanism in these systems.

This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

metadata.title:
Ferromagnetic Coupling in the Three-Dimensional Malonato-Bridged
Gadolinium(III) Complex [Gd2(mal)3(H2O)6] (H2mal = Malonic Acid)
